captions.text:
0:03 Road Atlanta, Braselton, Georgia
0:07 2015 Corvette Z06, Tommy Milner Hot Lap

Hi, I’m Tommy Milner, driver of the #4 Corvette
C7.R for Corvette Racing.

We’re here at Road Atlanta for a hot lap
in the all-new Corvette Z06,

With the 8-speed automatic transmission.
External Camera

Actual PDR Video Footage
Lap Time: 1:29.81

title: Road Atlanta: Corvette Racing’s Tommy Milner Takes the Z06 for a Hot Lap | Chevrolet

comments.author: Bryan Chevrolet

comments.text:
What's really interesting here is that Tommy had the transmission in manual 
shift mode, and laid down a faster lap than the other two pro drivers at 
the press event, who both used auto mode. Also note the minimal delay from 
paddle click to the actual shift, less than half a second there, assuming 
everything in the video is properly synced up. DCT-quick, just like GM 
claimed it to be.

However, I also noticed that, on the back straight the car's acceleration 
slowed down significantly at 120mph, and it really hit a wall at 140. I've 
seen stock C6 Z06s hit 150 on that back straight, and ZR1s do 160+, and 
that's with them not even carrying as much speed into the straight as the 
C7Z does. I'm assuming this is all down to the aero; all that downforce 
comes at the cost of aerodynamic drag, which kills top end speed. Oh well, 
this thing wasn't build for highway roll racing(which is illegal anyway)or 
the Texas Mile; it's a track weapon and I love it!﻿
comments.author: WelcomeToCarnate

comments.text:
+WelcomeToCarnate
Thanks a lot. A nice read too!
comments.author: Alpha Tyranax

comments.text:
+Philip Petracca Actually down shifts can be a big weakness of dual clutch 
transmissions, essentially with a dual clutch the computer has to guess 
what you are going to do next down shift or up shift. If it assumes an up 
shift and you give it a down shift this can result in a really slow down 
shift (near 1 second in some cases). This is because if you are in second 
gear and the second set is in 3rd gear it suddenly has to change that from 
3rd gear to 1st gear before it can execute the shift. 

Really there are many different types of transmissions with different pros 
and cons associated with them, no one transmission is the king of all 
transmissions.
comments.author: Duane Craig

comments.text:
You are spot on with your assumption about aerodynamics! That is the Z07 
trim, which adds so much downforce that it limits the top speed of that 
650hp car to a little over 180mph. The base trim Z06, with the same engine 
and in the same stretch, will hit 195mph or more. At those speeds, that 
15mph difference is very relevant.

I have only seen Milner's and Pobst's laps. May I ask you for the link to 
the other one you mentioned, please?
comments.author: Alpha Tyranax

comments.text:
+Adam Baldwin The Z06 is faster around Road Atlanta than any other stock 
DCT equipped car under a MILLION dollars - just give it props and don't be 
such a hater.   The A8 up shifts faster than the PDK - PDK has advantage on 
downshifts, but that doesn't effect lap times in relation to upshifts, 
where the time is really gained.   Plus, there's a big weight penalty with 
the DCT - which effects performance EVERYWHERE else.
comments.author: Philip Petracca

comments.text:
+Adam Baldwin
I'm not talking about the time it takes for the transmission to actually 
shift gears(which is actually a few HUNDRED milliseconds in most DCTs, even 
the fastest on the market, like the 911 GT3's PDK-S, are between 200 and 
100ms). I'm talking about the lag between the driver pressing the paddle 
and the transmission responding. I made that abundantly clear. Less than 
half a second is, indeed, DCT-quick.

And before you say it, no, paddle click to shift time is NOT measured in 
milliseconds. If it was, the shift would be instantaneous as soon as the 
paddle is pressed, but it's not. Not in any car, GT racers and F1 cars 
included. Well, it wouldn't actually be instant, but it would be to you and 
I, because the human brain can't even perceive milliseconds.
comments.author: WelcomeToCarnate

comments.text:
"less than half a second" is definitely NOT as quick as a DCT. Not even 
remotely close actually; the best DCTs out there will shift in a few 
milliseconds.

I've personally tested the A8 in the 2015 Corvette and the lag when 
manually shifting was TERRIBLE. Especially when double downshifting.
 -When will a DCT be an option for Corvette?
-Why did GM sell the A8 as a PDK competitor when it is definitely NOT?

The C7 was a ground up redesign, and there are DCT available from Getrag 
and others that fit Corvette spec and budget. I do NOT believe the excuses 
that GM is fabricating on why they continue to use an inferior truck 
transmission with a torque converter in the C7 instead of a proper DCT. GM 
needs to offer a DCT ASAP or loyal long time Corvette buyers like me will 
be lost to imports.﻿

comments.text:
The A8 has terrible lag and GM blatantly lied when comparing it to PDK. It 
needs a DCT.

http://jalopnik.com/ask-corvette-z06-chief-engineer-tadge-juechter-anything-1678938189

Tadge Jeuchter :
 " It might not be quite as quick in manual mode (as PDK) but in terms of 
speed of shift on the track it's wicked quick. The only way to assess it 
for the way you drive is to get in one and check it out."

http://www.corvetteforum.com/forums/c7-general-discussion/3530761-lag-time-for-the-new-8-speed-automatic-2.html#post1588599630

Supermassive (A8 owner) :  
"Look Ive put only 4000 miles on my C7 in the 2 months Ive had it and 
played with the manual mode enough to decide that its a gimmick for those 
that need to feel like they are in control of shifting the car. Upshifts 
are significantly quicker than downshifts, but they also are never 
immediate like a DCT. I know some people think the paddles are great, I 
however think a truly great paddle shifting auto is still quite a ways 
away. I think I'll make a PDR vid to show the lag during regular street 
driving and some spirited driving unless someone beats me to it. 
Anyone who thinks the paddles in the new A8 respond instantly have never 
driven a DCT plain and simple. The PDK is still king as far as paddle 
shifting is concerned. Although I prefer Ferrari's gearbox. 
To the people that think the paddles are great, good for you guys, if you 
never compare it to some of the great DCTs out there you will never miss 
it. If you are coming from DCTs and expecting the same response from the 
paddles, sorry its just not like that. Its not terrible but its also not 
the same connected feeling you get from a DCT."

http://www.kbb.com/car-news/all-the-latest/2015-corvette-stingray-inside-gms-new-8_speed-gearbox/2000011074/

The only gripe we had with the new automatic involved paddle shift response 
times. While GM claims its 8-speed can shift .08 seconds quicker than 
Porsche's PDK, there is still a noticeable delay between the time you 
depress the paddle shifter and the physical gear change. This, of course, 
is not an issue with PDK.

http://jalopnik.com/2015-corvette-z06-a-650-hp-all-american-middle-finger-1678181511

When you're hard on the throttle and driving aggressively, it's very quick 
and sharp on upshifts. While downshifts are fast, they don't feel like the 
gear is immediately locking in. At slower speeds, downshifts can produce a 
jerky rev match and upshifts are just too lazy. If they didn't say it was 
as good as PDK, there wouldn't really be any disappointment. It's like 
saying you're as good as Pete Sampras but you're really as good as Andre 
Agassi. 
Pro tip: Let it stand on its own and leave PDK out of it. The first rule of 
PDK is you don't talk about PDK.
http://jalopnik.com/the-eight-speed-automatic-corvette-stingray-does-not-su-1651785110
The General benchmarked this transmission against the PDK dual-clutch 
gearbox that Porsche uses. They say upshifts happen up to eight-hundredths 
of a second quicker than on the 911.
The thing is, the shifts just don't quite feel quite that fast. I'm sure 
they really are, but in terms of the speed of a gearshift, it just doesn't 
seem to be as instant as a dual-clutch or even the ZF8, the reigning 
champion of torque converter-based automatics. Still, it's good enough that 
I'd place it third below those two gearboxes, based on my own experiences. 
If it was my money on the line, I'd get the seven-speed manual gearbox. 
http://www.kbb.com/car-news/all-the-latest/2015-corvette-stingray-inside-gms-new-8_speed-gearbox/2000011074/

The only gripe we had with the new automatic involved paddle shift response 
times. While GM claims its 8-speed can shift .08 seconds quicker than 
Porsche's PDK, there is still a noticeable delay between the time you 
depress the paddle shifter and the physical gear change. This, of course, 
is not an issue with PDK.

ring times didn't make it in their first go and surely some of them 
spun/lost control during a fast lap attempt before posting their final 
times.

And don't forget the human factor. Any driver in any car can make a 
mistake, spin out and end up hitting a guardrail.
comments.author: Alpha Tyranax

comments.text:

were two Z06 there that weekend it germany.  Why no times?? Because they 
havent beat the ZR1

comments.text:
A Corvette is not a muscle car. A Camaro or a Mustang are.
Corvettes are competing in the sports/supercar pool nowadays. And doing a 
pretty good job at it, I must add.
comments.author: Alpha Tyranax

comments.text: No, no, no. That is called a muscle truck. ;)
comments.author: Alex Croak

comments.text:
+Alex Croak
Muscle cars are defined as your average family coupe with a high 
performance V8 engine. A small, light weight, high performance 2 seater 
describes a sports car, a car like the Corvette. If we were to use your 
description, that makes my uncle's rusted out '73 Ford pickup a muscle car.
comments.author: emdec55

comments.text:
Muscle car is usually associated with the pony car era of Challengers, 
Mustangs, and Camaros. Big chassis, big power, subpar handling. Sports car 
is a car with more finesse, but a big engine sure makes it better.
comments.author: EatPezzzz

comments.text:
A powerful, big displacement, V8 powered, 2-door high performance 
automobile basically sums up a muscle car. Although, I don't disagree with 
the "sports car" classification.
comments.author: Alex Croak

comments.text:
It's a sports car, i honestly hate when people refer to it as a muscle car. 
Nothing wrong with them, but a corvette is not one of them.
